subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: keyboard map uploaded
msgSnippet: Thanks for your enthused response. I have but one comment to speed back to you: Snip FALSE! . It was meant to replace & supplant ...
messageBody:
Thanks for your enthused response. I have but one
comment to speed back to you:

Snip>
FALSE! <sorry>. It was meant to replace & supplant
> the Orthodox way
> completely and in all situations; from print in
> newspapers to
> handwriting. It is a very complete system. It is not
> merely a
> shorthand.
+++++++++++++++++++

I agree it is (or rather could be) a complete system,
and no, it's not "just" a shorthand. But what I meant
was, it was born as a script. That is why is has the
word script in its name.

In Read's introduction to the manual, he boasts his
system uses "less labor" yet makes letters "as
neatly." These are the virtues of script. He writes:
"Is it not time for schools to teach a much simpler
script?" Later he boasts the "halving of pen work...
and of ink and paper." He goes on about strokes and
penlifts. Is this a script or what?

It is also interesting that no lead type of QS was
ever cut, whereas there were 3 printers fonts cut for
Shavian. And we must admit that in the last 40 odd
years QS has not exactly swept the world - a world
where letters are not written by hand anymore, and
good penmanship is as outdated as good manners.

This is not to say that the beauties and virtues of QS
should not be translated into lead - and now into
digital formats as well. Indeed, they should!

But that will be the subject of another email.

=====
Bob McBroom Woodstock NY"Begin the morning by saying to yourself, I shall meet with the busybody, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial. All these things happened to them by reason of their ignorance of what is good and evil. But I have seen the nature of the good, that it is beautiful, and of the bad, that it is ugly, and the nature of him who does wrong, that it is akin to mine, and participates in the same intelligence, and holds the same portion of divinity."- Marcus Aureliius
